Award.AwardTitle: CAREER:Shedding New Light on the Miracle of Life

Division.LongName: Div Of Chem, Bioeng, Env, & Transp Sys

Award.AbstractNarration:

P.I.: Audrey Ellerbee

The primary research objective of this CAREER Development Proposal (CDP) is to investigate the potential of morphological and biomechanical characteristics to predict viability in the early-stage embryo. This CDP incorporates a well integrated plan for research and education, and biomechanical characteristics to predict viability in the early-stage embryo. The broadly construed aims include: a) hardware development, b) software development, c) scientific experimentation, d) curricular enhancement, e) educational outreach, and f) science policy: This CDP will produce new hardware and software technology to investigate and fundamental questions about changes to the Aphysical properties of the embryo in the moments and hours following fertilization and early development, as well as use that technology to answer some such questions. Together with my collaborators, I will perform the first-in-human studies necessary to validate the relevance and significance of this methodology to address questions regarding fertility that are of broad interest to developmental biologists. In view of recent evidence of the predictive power of imaging-based markers for assessing the viability of embryos, the results of this CDP will likely transform the clinical practice of fertility treatments like in-vitro fertilization.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The research goal of this CAREER development proposal (CDP) was to extract novel morphological and biomechanical markers that are predictive of viability in the early-stage embryo. The proposed approach was to design a non-invasive, multimodal instrument and complementary software to study unique features of early-stage embryos. Our work was based primarily on the use of microscope-integrated optical coherence tomography, a high resolution technique for label-free imaging of the internal structure of scattering materials. We performed the first studies to identify distinguishable markers of vitrification in embryos, which is a common step in some assisted reproduction technologies. The intellectual merit of this proposal included new hardware and software that we produced to investigate fundamental questions about physical changes to the embryo in the moments and hours following fertilization. The broader imapcts of this work included new scientific information about the role of mitochondrial clustering in signaling changes to the embryo following vitrification that may lower the viabillity potential. This insight is important because fertility is a fundamental issue of high prevalence in society. In addition. this work included training of graduate students in cutting-edge science of this interdisciplinary field and encouraging diversity in STEM for women and under-represented minorities through development and teaching of new educational modules related to the content of this proposal.
